blog_graphql.tekstBlogaEng:
Hotel “Jadran” in Jelsa opened its door in May 1911

The idea of opening a hotel in Jelsa was suggested to captain Mihovil Zufić (1868-1921) back in 1905 by Jure Duboković (1877-1951), informing that the company NAD would finance both the construction and purchasing the hotel equipment. The hotel had 60 beds and was at that time one of the best equipped hotels in Dalmatia. The rooms had elegant furniture brought from Vienna, while porcelain and silver cutlery were bought in England. The hotel had a reading room and a piano, and the dining room could host 400 people at once. Frano Keko Duboković (1866 – 1929) was in charge of the quality and the furniture, and he put his soul in it. Captain Zufić, who opened and managed the hotel, had s distinguished chevalier’s style which made Jelsa a renowned name. The hotel closed its door in 1913, as the First World War was approaching. After the war it had an array of different managers and from 1934 till 1943 the manager was the son of captain Mihovil, Blaženko Zufić. From 1947 the hotel Jadran was back in business…

From an article by Rino Grgićević “Development of tourism in Jelsa”, by kind permission of Mrs. Lukrecija Benković Duboković

 

What is interesting about this hotel is that a series of its promotional postcards is among the most beautiful tourist postcards of Dalmatia till 1940, as well as a true collector’s delicacy. Today we are familiar with as much as eight samples from the series printed in 1911, showing the hotel lobby, dining room, room interiors, bathing area (3 samples) and hotel exterior (2 samples), but it is not excluded that there is still a sample which has not yet been found. This tells us enough on the entrepreneurship of captain Zufić and his sense of marketing. There are very few small towns in Dalmatia of that time which can brag with such a tourism photography legacy. Some of the postcards from the series were published in the monograph “Greetings from Dalmatia long forgotten”.

 

Igor Goleš

Hotel Jadran u Jelsi započeo je s radom u svibnju 1911. g.

Prijedlog o otvaranju hotela u Jelsi dao je još  1905. g. Jure Duboković (1877. – 1951.) kapetanu  Mihovilu Žufiću (1868. – 1921.) s tim da bi tvrtka NAD financirala izgradnju i nabavu namještaja te opreme za hotel.

Hotel je raspolagao sa 60 kreveta i bio, za ono vrijeme, jedan od najbolje opremljenih u Dalmaciji.  Sobe su bile namještene elegantnim namještajem nabavljenim u Beču, a porculan i srebrni  pribor za jelo u Engleskoj. Imao je čitaonicu i klavir, a blagovaonica je mogla ugostiti 400 ljudi odjednom. Za kvalitetu i namještaj zdušno se brinuo Frano Keko Duboković (1866. – 1929.). Kap. Žufić, koji je otvorio i vodio hotel, svojim kavalirskim stilom stvorio je odmah renomirano ime Jelsi. Hotel je 1913., u osvit I. svjetskog rata, neko vrijeme prestao s radom, a  kasnije su se redale razne uprave, da bi ga od 1934. do 1943. vodio sin kap. Mihovila, Blaženko Žufić.  Od 1947. Hotel Jadran nastavlja s radom…

 (podatci preuzeti iz članka Rina Grgičevića “Razvoj turizma u Jelsi”, dobrotom gospođe Lukrecije Benković Duboković)

 

Zanimljivost ovog hotela je i u tome što serija njegovih promidžbenih razglednica spada među najljepše turističke  u Dalmaciji do 1940., te su kolekcionarske poslastice. Danas je poznato čak 8 primjeraka iz serije otisnute 1911. koje prikazuju  predvorje hotela, blagovaonicu, interijere soba, kupalište (3 primjerka ), te eksterijer hotela (2 primjerka), ali nije isključeno da ne postoji još neki primjerak koji do sada nije pronađen. To dovoljno govori o poduzetnosti kapetana Žufića i njegovom smislu za marketing. Vrlo malo manjih gradića u Dalmaciji tog vremena može se pohvaliti takvom turističkom fotografskom ostavštinom. Neke od razglednica iz serije su objavljene u monografiji Pozdrav iz zaboravljene Dalmacije.

 

Igor Goleš
